fields.descriptive_line: Set of toy soldiers, Nazi Sturmabteilung (SA) troops (brownshirts), fifteen soldiers, five horses and four flags, hand-painted composite material (Elastolin) and printed metal, Lineol and O M Hausser, Germany, 1930s.
fields.physical_description:
[flag bearers] Four identical hand-painted composite figures dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the  German Nazi Party. With brown kepis and shirts, darker brown trousers and gloss brown knee-length boots. Details such as buttons and insignia on the uniformas are picked out in black and silver paint, and each has a red armband on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background. Each has a bag, painted light blue, hanging from their right shoulder, and are standing on a grey base. Hands and faces are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. Their right arms are at their sides, their left arms are crossed across their chest. A hole in their left and allows a metal flagpole to be inserted, the end of the pole resting on their right hand.   
[officers] Three hand-painted composite figures dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the German Nazi Party. With brown kepis and shirts, darker brown trousers and gloss brown knee-length boots. Details such as buttons and insignia on the uniformas are picked out in black and silver paint, with one having red and green colar patches and a red-topped kepi. Each has a red armband on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background, and is standing on a grey base. Hands and faces are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. Their right arms are at their sides, their left arms are at their belts.    
[trumpeter] Hand-painted composite figure dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the German Nazi Party. With brown kepis and shirts, darker brown tunic and  trousers and gloss brown knee-length boots. Details such as buttons and insignia on the uniform is picked out in black and silver paint, and a belt is painted also in darker brown. A red armband is worn on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background. The figure is standing on a grey base. Hands and faces are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. The left arm is at the belt, the right arm holds a large, gold-painted trumpet to the lips.    
[seated soldier] Hand-painted composite figure dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the  German Nazi Party. With brown kepis and tunic, darker brown trousers and gloss brown knee-length boots. Insignia on the kepis is picked out in silver paint, and figure wears a red armband on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background. A bag, painted light blue, hangs from the left shoulder, and hands and faces are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. The figure is seated on the ground, eating from a bowl painted silver..   
[motorbike rider] Hand-painted composite figure dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the  German Nazi Party. With brown shirt, darker brown trousers and gloss brown knee-length boots. The figure wears a black helmet and goggles. and brown gloves. A bag, painted light blue, hangs from the right shoulder. Insignia on the uniform is picked out in black silver paint, and figure wears a red armband on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background. Hands and face are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. The figure is riding a motorcycle, with red fuel tank and mudguards, black details around the engine area, seat and spokes, and grey tyres. The areas between the spokes and around the engine is painted white, and light brown paniers hang either side of the rear wheel. The handlebars are formed from part of the wire armature, and the whole is supported upright by a metal stand which has been inserted into the base of the rear wheel.  
[mounted soldiers] Three hand-painted composite figures dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the German Nazi Party. With brown kepis and shirts, darker brown ties, trousers and gloss brown knee-length boots and belts. Details such as buttons and insignia on the uniforms are picked out in black and silver paint, with one having additional  insignia on the left breast picked out in red, white and blue. Each has a red armband on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background. Hands and faces are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. Their right arms are at their sides, their left arms at their belt as if holding reins. Their legs are splayed to allow them to sit on a horse, and a metal pin protrudes from between their legs which fits into a hole on the back of the horse and keeps the figures in place.   
[horses] Hand-painted composite horse, painted in light and dark brown, with darker brown mane and tail. Has brown saddle bags and saddle, and grey saddle blanket and rolled blanket, with a light-blue girdle. The hooves are black, with white forelegs, and the horse stands, with one foreleg raised, on a grey base. In the middle of the saddle is a hole into which the metal pin attached to the riders fits.  
[horses - hausser] Hand-painted composite horse, painted in light and dark brown, with darker brown mane and tail. Has brown saddle bags and lighter brown saddle with light-brown girdle, with a red saddle blanket, edged in gold and featuring the Nazi swastika in black within a white circle on both sides. The hooves are black, with white forelegs, and the horse stands, with one foreleg raised, on a brown base. Protruding from the saddle is a metal pin which can locate into a hole between the legs of mounted soldiers to attach them securely to the horse.  
[mounted soldiers - hausser] Hand-painted composite figures dressed in the uniform of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the German Nazi Party. With brown kepis and shirts, darker brown ties, trousers and tunic and gloss brown knee-length boots and belts. Details such as buttons and insignia on the uniforms are picked out in black and silver paint, with one having additional  insignia on the collar and kepi picked out in red and gold. Each has a red armband on the left arm with the Nazi swastika in black on a white background. Hands and faces are painted flesh-coloured, with facial details picked out in black and red paint. Their left arms at their belt as if holding reins. The right arm of one is raised in a Nazi salute. Their legs are splayed to allow them to sit on a horse, and there is a hole between their legs into which a metal pin protruding from the saddles of the horses fits to keep the figures in place.   
[flags] Four flags, made of pressed tin shaped to resemble fabric moving in the wind, folded around a thin metal pole. The tin has been printed on both sides in red, with a black Nazi swastika in black within a white circle. At the top is a thin strip painted gold. The pole is unpainted.

fields.name: Museum of Childhood, Temporary Exhibition Gallery

fields.public_access_description:
This group of toy soldiers, representing Nazi Sturmabteilung (or SA) troops, also known as 'Brownshirts', was not originally sold as a set, but is made up of individual pieces, from two separate manufacturers, purchased separately and brought together. The majority of the figures were manufactured by A. G. Lineol, a leading German manufacturer of toy soldiers, but the set also includes figures produced by O. & M. Hausser, Lineol's main competitor and another major manufacture of soldiers and other games. All of the figures were manufactured in Germany in the mid- to late-1930s. 

They are made from a composite material, which includes substances such as plaster, glue, sawdust, and  linseed oil mixed together, which is then pressed into a mould around a wire armature, heated and dried and then hand-painted. The particular composite mixture used by Hausser was given the trade name 'Elsastolin'. 

They reflect the trend amongst toy manufacturers to mirror the real world in terms of new armies, regiments, changes in uniform and  equipment and methods of warfare. Although, through representing the SA, the figures can be read as an example of propaganda, it is unclear how much official encouragement, on the part of the German Government, for the manufacture of these politically-based figures existed at the time. It is likely that toys such as this were produced to  satisfy a general demand amongst the German population caused by the political climate of the time.
fields.history_note: This set is made up of individual figures collected together, produced by two different manufacturers - the majority of figures were produced by Lineol, with two mounted soldiers and horses produced by O M Hausser. They were purchased at auction in May 2011. Their history subsequent to manufacture before acquisition is unknown.
fields.historical_context_note: As toys, these soldiers would have originally been played with by children, although objects such as these have subsequently become popular with adult collectors. They reflect the trend amongst toy manufacturers, especially manufacturers of toy soldiers, to mirror the real world in terms of newly formed regiments, armies, changes in uniform and equipment and methods of warfare. They were produced as accurate representations of the Sturmabteilung (SA) troops  (brownshirts) of the German Nazi Party.
